title: Worldpay to raise £890m through stock market float
text:

Fri, Sep 18, 2015, 10:25 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 5 mins Worldpay to raise £890m through stock market float By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 5 minutes ago 0.0000 
Payments processor has announced plans to list on London's main market in October 
British payments company Worldpay has announced plans to float on the stock market in October, a move that will take it straight into the FTSE 100. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) intends to raise about £890m from the offer to help reduce debt, recruit more staff and fund expansion. 
The decision to press ahead with an initial pulic offering comes despite Worldpay attracting interest from French rival Ingenico (Paris: FR0000125346 - news ) and other interested bidders who had valued the company at more than £6bn 
Chief executive Philip Jansen described the listing as “an exciting next step” for the business. 
“It will enable us to access new capital for growth, augment our global position and further enhance our ability to serve customers across the world,” he said. 
Since becoming an independent company five years ago, the group has invested over £1bn back into the company Mr Jansen said. 
The global payments company processes roughly 31 million mobile, online and in-store transactions a day, across 326 payment methods in 126 currencies across 146 countries, serving individuals and small-to-medium sized businesses. 
Every year it supports about £370bn worth of payments from 400,000 merchants. * Worldpay pushing bidders for higher offers Last year Worldpay made a £374.7m underlying cash profit on sales of £863.4m. 
In the first six months of this year, sales rose 13pc to £465.7m, pushing profits up by the same amount to £182.6m. 
Headquartered in London, Worldpay was carved out of RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) five years ago and established as a standalone business by private equity firms Advent International and Bain Capital - who paid £1.7bn for the business. 
With consumer behaviour increasingly shifting away from cash payments, Worldpay now process approximately 40pc of web-based transactions in Europe, and is increasing its exposure in emerging markets. 
Commenting on its intention to float, chairman of the group Sir Michael Rake said: “Worldpay aims to lead the way in expanding the global reach, data analytics and optimisation, and emerging field of integrated payments.” 
Worldpay expects to pay 20 to 30pc of profits in dividends each year to shareholders, with the first payment scheduled for late 2016. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Ingenico leapt more than 14pc on the news and the stock is now on track to enjoy its best one-day gain in more than 12 years. 
Shares in the French company had slumped amid reports it had submitted a bid for Worldplay. It was suggested it may offer as much as £6.66bn as it was interested in Worldpay’s European operations (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
